Please note the nova barely supports neutron existing multisegment feature. For example if you are using sriov networking then in a mutlisegment network only the first segment can be sriov, otherwise PCI scheduling will fail in nova. Also if you are using numa aware vswitches feature then you cannot have mutliple ovs segments either.

The nova limitation starts here: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c8940f9d60f1b0290ebea94fb6174efac9a1632e/nova/network/neutron.py#L2026-L2034

yeah it is not easy to say which one to use that is why proxy APIs are not good interfaces and we have deprecated them in nova side. basically build timeout we add for any service we are interacting via API and in proxy APIs we interact to compute service and then compute service interact to image and return the response. If we take example of any other non-proxy API, in that case also main service might be calling other service to get/perform something (for example create server, nova interact to glance and neutron also) but we use the main service timeout.

But on the same time, another argument can be, main time in proxy APIs case are proceeded by proxy service only so we can say using proxy service timeout is right choice.

Anyways those APIs are deprecated and not recommended to use so let's go with what we did for volume in client you pointed out. But can you please add same comment here too so that we know why we are using image build timeout here.

hooks/cinder_utils.py.message: Why not migrate in this case ? The db is being sync, so it seems strange to not perform the workaround if `upgrade` is false.

If it's not an upgrade scenario, then this is the initial database population (db sync). In that scenario, the tables should be empty and there should be no online_data_migrations to run and so it must be some other error. This check is essentially a short circuit as the rest of the code is not necessary to run and we've run into a real error.
log level should be INFO, otherwise the operator won't know about this condition in a default configuration (juju set unit=INFO)

Based on the docs here:

https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/admin/upgrades.html

it seems like all upgrades since ocata need to run 'cinder-manage db sync' followed by a loop running 'cinder-manage db online_data_migrations' while the exit status is 1 and stop once the exit status is 0 or 2 (errors requiring intervention). Should we code it that way?

aha!, good catch, yeah, we assumed that 2 runs were enough, but loop until the exit code is 0 or 2 is the way to go, this will become noticeable for larger busier clouds. I will follow up with a patch.

This fix is very targeted. It prevents the blocking of the user logging on or sudo usage if for some reason sssd service is down and can be down for multiple reasons.
There is a side effect that occurs in the tests you outlined. The fix will disable the password reset feature for new users when logging in the first time. The side effect will be resolved in an upcoming separate commit.

No, the "ignore" means if the pam module return any values other than these specified in that line, it will be ignored, and authentication considered passed.

fcntl(3, F_SETLK, {l_type=F_RDLCK, l_whence=SEEK_SET, l_start=1073741824, l_len=1}) = -1 ENOLCK (No locks available)

I reproduced the same "cannot obtain lock error" with the code. I prefer this "python native" flock function over wrapper fcntl.fcntl function call with c structure, which implies compatibility issue that might crash the process if mismatch.

That being said, is 'capabilities:volume_backend_name' really a thing?

  $ grep -I -R -F -n 'capabilities:volume_backend_name' cinder/*
  cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/powermax/common.py:49:PREFIXBACKENDNAME = 'capabilities:volume_backend_name'
  $ grep -I -R -F -n 'PREFIXBACKENDNAME' cinder/*
  cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/powermax/common.py:49:PREFIXBACKENDNAME = 'capabilities:volume_backend_name'
  
So although dell defines it, it doesn't actually seem to be used anywhere.

The capabilities filter strips off 'capabilities:' [0], so if the extra_specs have both 'v_b_n' and 'cap:v_b_n' keys and they have different values, the extra_specs will never match anything (because a backend will only have one name).  So if you do think you may get 'capabilities:volume_backend_name' in an extra_spec, we need to handle that in the 'if backend_name' clause (though I'm not sure exactly what we should do).

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/1a231d3d2e9fcd3945b67cf7b8d7a8dda3c76e2a/cinder/scheduler/filters/capabilities_filter.py#L64

The change is based on tempest existing code,

> An assertion that an attempt to open file '/dev/null' should be added.

I didn't catch your suggestion here. Do you mean using mock_open?

By not using mock_open, this test is currently actually reading from /dev/null before going on to the mocked JSON value. Given that the function under test is reading a file and then parsing it as JSON, it would be better to mock the open / read calls with the expected JSON output and let the parsing handle that, rather than mocking the return value and ignoring the open calls entirely

extraconfig/nova_metadata/krb-service-pr.message: If we change fqdns to use dns_domain in networks below we need to change it here as well?

Maybe to clarify, the user might want CloudName to be separate from the network's dns_domain. For example external:
```
CloudName: openstack.example.com
external_dns_domain: nodes.external.example.com
```

CloudName is for overcloud.internalapi.openstack.lab for example, which is a single entry, and should be constructed according to the user needs. These are already documented well enough in the TLS-e part, except for adding other networks like Provisioning

ctlplane is never in 'networks'.

ctlplane is however always there, so you can handle it outside the for loop. See above on L103.
Good point, forgot to remove that. It is handled on L125 below

What about {get_param: CloudName{{network.name}}}?
There are parameters to control the domain of the networks, i.e we cannot just assume it is derived from name_lower here.

CloudName includes `overcloud` hostname part which we don't want. If we can trim that out with heat, that would be ideal. Please let me know if it can be done, otherwise it is handled on the tripleo_ipa side.

> There are parameters to control the domain of the networks, i.e we cannot just assume it is derived from name_lower here.

Indeed that's what this is trying to achieve. My assumption is that in order to customize this, the user has to use network.dns_domain. If there is a different way, let me know

failure unrelated
I agree, but to the letter of the standard as I read it just returning [GET, OPTIONS] as methods for these pages, with a blank body-content, is appropriate anyway.

OPTIONS calls are only used by browsers when implementing CORS preflight checks on endpoints that expect arguments IIRC, I wouldn't worry too much about return values outside of the cases that are already covered by the decorator.

I did think about this, but I'm not sure what it should be returning.  

curl -X OPTIONS https://<site> gives:

* google -- 405 with Allow: headers (google.com).  
* wikipedia.org -- 405 without allow: headers (www.wikipedia.org).
* developer.mozilla.org -- 403 (error from cloudfront)

I think this is the simplest approach.  I can propose a simple follow-on with a wrapper and we can discuss it there.
https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/832731 implements this general idea

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> Instead of updating the methods, how about updating the route dispatcher?

After thinking about this; I think this doesn't achieve quite what this is going for.  Setting up a conditional match in the route dispatcher [1] will just mean that the request doesn't match and doesn't trigger the handling function call, and falls through to a 404.  What this is going for is actually matching the request, but if it has an unsupported method rejecting it with a 405

[1] https://routes.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setting_up.html#conditions

should not be a breaking change unless someone is explicitly passing "" in an environment file? probably heat will just convert that to number?

i cant find any explicit "" in our envs e.g. https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/24829bc6ccbc9e92bfc1adf682f488edefcd57aa/environments/low-memory-usage.yaml#L10

Heat no longer accepts '' and deployment fails at the early stage when creating a heat stack. For this specific parameter we have never supported usage of '' and in case you put '' then the value is directly put to the config file and keystone can't start (that's what is validated by this change)

For some parameters such as NeutronWorkers, '' is not treated as a 'special' value so in case users define the value in their template then the stack creation fails because of validation failure. However IMO '' is not meant for actual usage and in case the default is needed then the users should remove the wrong parameter definition from their template.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: One suggestion -- and a thought mentioned elsewhere about whether or not it's beneficial to spin and see if this condition is transient before concluding that the migration is completed.

This change looks good. Previously reviewers requested a release note to go along with a fix for this, so if you can add one or copy the previous one [1], it would be good.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/842687/4/releasenotes/notes/libvirt-workaround-no-ram-info-was-set-6f3f6dbc751d6b66.yaml

this would also work but I have approved. 
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/842687 instead since it was already reviewed, has a release note and a similar level of test coverage.

I've pulled my patch out of the gate because upon further inspection, I think it will not work properly.

I think the approach in this patch is what needs to be done.

I've managed to reproduce this today and added additional logic and logging when the libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR is observed (sorry, it's sloppy...):
https://paste.opendev.org/show/bNq9IPAZLarlSwThfodZ/

The additional logic re-invokes `self._domain.jobStats()` up to 10x with 100ms sleeps in between after first observing the libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR. In doing so, I observed that it is possible that we get a dict with 'type: 2' in the response, or libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED, indicating that the migration is still active.

Thus, I believe it's not safe to conclude that libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR means the migration has completed based on the above. The patch is definitely on the right track though, and even as-is prevents the migration from erroring out (it just coerces Nova into thinking that the migration finished earlier than it actually does).

Please let me know if anyone disagrees with this analysis, or would like more information gathered.

(and note that even the "fix" which I posted above in the paste is *still* not correct -- because it's possible that *another* exception gets thrown while doing the nested `self._domain.jobStats()`, in which case we may have to raise a subsequent libvirt.VIR_ERR_NO_DOMAIN or libvirt.VIR_ERR_OPERATION_INVALID error into a finished migration...)

Looks OK to me. +1 for now, I want to try to write a test  or find a test verifying that handling of this scenario (and other similar ones) properly call post_live_migration after they are handled.

Want to get more eyes on this too.
Release note added.

i have some thing i need to get in order before the feature freeze so im gong to focus on that this week. however if melanine things this is the better approch i will review this once i have time.

thanks for adding the release note.
Looked again today, and now I see how finish_event is used -- my concern above was unfounded.  This should work great, and the reproducer we have agrees. Great job!
Hit this condition several times this weekend on our reproducer, but with the patch changed to return type=libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_NONE, instead. It seems to work great!

I'm happy to give it a try on our reproducer -- eyeing the code quickly, it's not clear to me when and when not the finish_event.ready() branch is taken... in the case it's not taken, it looks like find_job_type() will raise VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_FAILED [1] because the guest is active on the source in the event the migration is still active, though?

Here [2] is another approach that also works -- it changes the function signature and relies on recursion though... your type=libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_NONE is much, much cleaner I think.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e413ac015f7b5cbfb7b1ac98ca02afc700e0a6b7/nova/virt/libvirt/migration.py#L435
[2] https://paste.opendev.org/show/bBFVEgM1si5SoChuH3m0/

Thanks for your testing and analysis! - I confirms the suspicions that my debug message alludes too.

If we return JobInfo with type=libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_NONE I wonder if we can reuse this [1] infrastructure to continue the migration until it eventually meets one of the expected completion states.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/4c7d81ebca52d2b63d4ad819b58953e285864337/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L10134-L10139

Interesting, and nice work! Thank you for doing that. I agree this is worth looking into further.

I wonder if we could do something like ignore the "no RAM info set" any time we encounter it and then let monitoring continue until it hits one of the other expected "completion" conditions, then we call it complete. (That is, assuming the migration does hit an expected completion state eventually.)

If we could avoid erroneously considering a migration complete when it really isn't, that would be ideal.

To be clear, once I saw this patch I realized that the patch I had proposed will not work correctly as I think it would prevent post_live_migration from running.

The approach in this patch will run post_live_migration after catching "no RAM info set".

I realize as I type this, it's probably worth adding test coverage that asserts post_live_migration is called after the scenario happens. Since it's not directly related to this patch and it would also apply to other libvirt exception handling, I think it could be its own follow up patch.
Looks good to me

Apologies for taking so long to get back to this patch. I have finally uploaded a test coverage follow up patch for this one and it exercises that the post live migration method is properly called after this exception is raised along the way.

So all LGTM, thank you Brett and Tyler!
Let's get this merged, please.  It does solve an annoying problem.

nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py.message: Not sure you need this part but of course it doesn't hurt.
Perhaps this is better at LOG.warning? Operators generally do not run with debug=true and this condition hit frequently is a sign of some kind of issue that likely needs more investigation.

IMHO I think debug is appropriate. It's consistent with the other messages and this condition is unfortunately not avoidable when it happens (because it's due to a bug/behavior in qemu). There is no action an operator can take for this, so a warning log level for this may cause unnecessary alarm.

I believe the race condition is this:
https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2022-04/msg01395.html

My 2c here:
If there is either a) a high degree of confidence in the above patch or similar, or b) a reproducer for this race condition (please share details!), then I agree it's best served at debug. If not, though, raising it to warn will help determine if and when the underlying race condition is fixed out in the field at scale.
My 2c - I'd would find it awkward that we would throw a warning but then pass the migration. As an operator I'd be concerned it was indicative of /some/ malfunction in nova.

You are correct, that is the race condition that is suspected.

Fair point on detecting if and when the race condition is fixed.

If this race happens rarely (and so far, my understanding is that it is rare) then warning might be OK. What we don't want is for this to be logged so often that it becomes noise.

In my experience, warnings are generally used to signal to the operator that they should do something, check something, or let them know that something unexpected has happened. I thought this didn't quite fit into that category.

I don't feel strongly about it though, so if most people prefer warning, that is OK with me. If we do use warning, I think it should also mention that no action is needed.

Thanks for the confirmation on the patch.

For hard #s in one use case - in about a week's time of pushing around ~15k VMs, I saw it happen a dozen times per our telemetry.

Rethinking this -- if we leave this as debug, I can advocate to deploy it as a warning in our deployment and make sure that the qemu patch addresses the race condition when we get around to incorporating it (and if so, I'll update the LP with findings). All I really want to see here is that we don't rely on this branch unknowingly in the long-term.
For VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_NONE the caller will try to figure out the status of the migration based on the instance status in nova.virt.libvirt.migration.find_job_type() which probably work OK.

fyi we have name conflicts but they only happen when openstacksdk is used with old openstack releases. Rafael's code handles these by filtering them.

  compute_quota_set_keys = sorted(openstack.compute.v2.quota_set.QuotaSet().to_dict(computed=False).keys())
  network_quota_keys = sorted(openstack.network.v2.quota.Quota().to_dict(computed=False).keys())
  block_storage_quota_set_keys = sorted(openstack.block_storage.v3.quota_set.QuotaSet().to_dict(computed=False).keys())

  > set()

  set(compute_quota_set_keys) & set(block_storage_quota_set_keys) - set(["id", "name"])
  > {'reservation', 'usage'}

@zzzeek Would be interested in your thoughts on this. I've proposed a similar change in nova but suspect other projects would benefit from this.

I'm pretty skeptical on this one.  Whether a model does "soft delete" or "real delete" tends to be kind of a Big Deal, with direct implications for database integrity and such (think rows that are referenced by foreign key) as well as transactional isolation behaviors, and doesn't seem like something that end users would be flipping on and off in the configuration file.    Most concerning would be that applications would not be fully tested with the configuration in both positions, as this is a major, fundamental behavioral change.

Realistically, it's the kind of thing you'd be configuring on a per-model basis in a specific app for specific models where people want an option here, and if the app is exposing this through the conf file, it would need to have full test coverage for both scenarios.   Even then, I think it's a very difficult feature to support since supporting two different scenarios of deletion introduces a lot of behavioral branches.


I'd want to start with the background and problem space on this one and figure out the best solution.   My impression is that in practice, "soft delete" has not been very useful and we'd like to be using "hard delete" so that we don't have tons of old records lying around.   I think making a real shift towards that model, *or* at least moving to an "archive row" model, where deleted rows are moved out to archive tables that are easier to truncate, would likely be a more robust course of action.
Yup, definitely need to think about this one more.

why not just remove soft delete from nova altogether?  

as for the config here, it's one thing if it works for Nova, OK.  but I'd be really nervous about like, Neutron flipping *anything*.  neutron probably isn't using soft delete, I'd have to check.    Soft delete is a real matter of preference, so overall while this class is here, doesnt feel like an "oslo.db" thing to me.   Maybe a class-level attribute that Nova can configure instead.

> I'm pretty skeptical on this one.  Whether a model does "soft delete" or "real delete" tends to be kind of a Big Deal, with direct implications for database integrity and such (think rows that are referenced by foreign key) as well as transactional isolation behaviors, and doesn't seem like something that end users would be flipping on and off in the configuration file.

This is a good point. I know that nova historically avoided use of foreign key constraints, meaning we wouldn't be able to rely on DELETE CASCADE behavior to delete e.g. everything that points to a newly deleted instance. I'll have to inspect how nova is doing it's DB archive though to see how this is figured out.

> Most concerning would be that applications would not be fully tested with the configuration in both positions, as this is a major, fundamental behavioral change.

Also a valid point. I _suspect_ nova could immediately toggle this in CI jobs to test the "new way" while relying on our existing unit and functional tests for the DB archive functionality to ensure nothing breaks with the "old way". Can't say this for every project though.

> Realistically, it's the kind of thing you'd be configuring on a per-model basis in a specific app for specific models where people want an option here, and if the app is exposing this through the conf file, it would need to have full test coverage for both scenarios.   Even then, I think it's a very difficult feature to support since supporting two different scenarios of deletion introduces a lot of behavioral branches.
> 
> 
> I'd want to start with the background and problem space on this one and figure out the best solution.   My impression is that in practice, "soft delete" has not been very useful and we'd like to be using "hard delete" so that we don't have tons of old records lying around.

👆 yeah, this. See also [1] from waaay back (feeling old yet?)

> I think making a real shift towards that model, *or* at least moving to an "archive row" model, where deleted rows are moved out to archive tables that are easier to truncate, would likely be a more robust course of action.

Funnily enough this is what nova has - namely, you've to run two commands to first archive rows and then truncate the archive tables - and there are complaints that the prune functionality found in other projects (straight up DELETEs) is simpler an therefore preferable.

(As an aside, one issue we have found with the archiving model is that MySQL resets the auto-increment counter after the service is restarted. If you delete a row with ID N and 'max(ID for each remaining row) < N', then an ID of N will eventually be assigned to a new row and you'll get a conflict when you try to archive that new row. Great fun)

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/mitaka/implemented/no-more-soft-delete.html

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: It seems, that with adding conditional on duration, there are far less cpu_util data points generated. Besides, I haven't been able to find the usage of duration in other inspectors. Is it really necessary?

I'd think the path here to finally fix this is to use the following https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/aodh/+/829870 which would then allow to get the utilitization calculated in gnocchi as proposed during the rocky development cycle.

Just to be clear: I'm not the reviewer, I've just found this patch, while trying to solve similar need:
I need to get CPU utilization as percent on a scale from 0 to 100 (independent of vCPU count) from Gnocchi and I've found this change (thank you, btw!). 

I've ended up fixing this a little bit (just removing `duration` at all, as, like I've said earlier, I haven't found any other place in ceilometer where it is getting used (sometimes it gets accepted at some methods, but that's all) and with it, I've got less data points). 

Here's my fix: https://paste.opendev.org/show/buKIdHuHGzSS0EKYcPXH/.

I'm retrieving this data directrly from Gnocchis' API with this query:

`(/ (resample mean {period} (metric cpu_util rate:mean)) 300)`

I don't know, if Aodh allows passing more advanced queries to Gnocchi, but this whole thing could've been achieved without adding another metric with this query:

`(/ (aggregate mean (/ (metric cpu rate:mean) (metric vcpus mean))) 60000000000))`

But, there is a missing bit for `fill` behaviour on Gnocchi side: https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/issues/1266

I needed to get the same percent utilization for memory, and for that, I've found this abandoned patch: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ceilometer/+/597054.

Yes, calculating this in Gnocchi would be the best approach, but as of now it would result in significantly less data (only one point per hour (depends on `vcpus` metric discretization), as with this query you'll get points in the resulting set only on intersections of measures, see: https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/issues/1266). 

So this whole thing is more like a workaround for current Gnocchi's behaviour.

I'll look into why 'duration' is not always available..

The idea is to pre-calculate this metric as much as possible. It is (was) quite common to use cpu_util metric as driver for alarming (Aodh) and autoscaling (Heat), but users can not write complex aggregations in AODH alarm, only <metric> or rate:<metric>

The 'cpu' (ns) is the only metric that libvirt provides. To transform it to cpu utilization in % one has to have a diff between two consecutive 'cpu' metrics and divide by time between them (and some more):

  100* (CPU_n - CPU_n-1) / ( (T_n - T_n-1) * 10**9 * Nvcpus )
  
The plan was to split this into

  CPU_n / (...) - CPU_n-1 / (...)
  
where each part we can calculate locally in compute agent (relying on duration being more or less constant), and the diff might be provided by rate:... aggregation in Gnocchi.

If that does not work, quite possibly we'd need a local cache to store the previous value of 'cpu' metric and time it was collected at, so we can generate final cpu_util all by ourselves. This is essentially how virt-manager does this:

https://github.com/virt-manager/virt-manager/blob/1d64a678d31829051444e1bf29d86f800e13de39/virtManager/lib/statsmanager.py#L178-L180

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
First and foremost, you have done A LOT for the OpenStack community and there is no amount of thanks we can really give. You have pushed so much change and progress and we have grown as a community under your leadership. 

That said, I feel like a change in leadership might be a good idea. We have an endemic of burnout in the community and too short a bench for people to step up into leadership roles. I think handing over the reigns to help someone else grow and share the load is really what we should be encouraging, not just amongst the TC, but also in PTLs. Having a group of skilled leadership folk to pass the role around to would go a long way to preventing the burnout that we see all too often.

Plus changing leadership is good once in a while :) It's literally one of our principles: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/principles.html#changes-in-leadership-are-good. While I wasn't as vocal as I should have been about my stepping down, I did, after serving for I honestly can't remember how many terms now.. 2 years? 3 maybe? I want to make space for new folks to join the Technical committee and encourage new people to take up new roles for the health of our community and the project we all pour so much of ourselves into.
I may not be able to do a rolecall vote, but I vote +1 to this.  Gmann has done a wonderful job of leading and if he feels he is able to continue, I fully support it.
I've reviewed the election results; they show gmann the winner by a vote of 5-4.
Thanks for being willing to serve as chair!  Your candidacy LGTM.  (And also, thank you for all your past service.)
This confirms the election result.
merging it as per election result and formal-vote criteria.

Is this really appropriate as a comment on someone's self-nomination for this position? If this is your feedback privately to gmann that's cool, but I think it's probably best to encourage people to volunteer for thankless positions like this, especially in the current climate we have where volunteers are hard to come by. I think it's clear that gmann running again doesn't prevent anyone else from being considered, as we already have another person nominating themselves for the position. I think your comment here kinda casts an unfair shadow on the pending vote in a way that anonymous voting is intended to prevent.

I think gmann does an amazing job as chair, an amazing amount of work as a result, and I think the TC is lucky he hasn't ragequit yet. That's not to say that someone else wouldn't also do a good job, but I think we should not *discourage* people in this way and, honestly, I'm sad to see it :(

I actually think it'll work fine, the import structure is opportunistically use the stdlib import `importlib.metadata` and fallback to `importlib_metadata` on a `ImportError`, so for python > 3.7 we'll never try using the pypi package because the stdlib import is present. This means capping the version on 3.7 only like this will maintain compatibility for the supported Python versions on stevedore 3.5.x. That being said updating the API usage to use the new API is fine from my perspective I just assumed it was too big/risky a change for a stable branch backport which is why I opted to just cap on the stable branch where we still support 3.7.

I don't have a strong preference either way as long as we get a release out for Python 3.7 that works, because right now unless you manually cap importlib-metadata stevedore will error on 3.7.

This won't work. While stevedore will only install importlib-metadata on Python 3.7, other packages can install it and we'll use it opportunistically. I've proposed [1]. I think that's probably a better, long-term fix?

I agree with defaulting SSL verification to False; but it feels like the wrong thing to do in terms of security. You're claiming that the backend doesn't support SSL verification --- but that's not how this is supposed to work; the python SSL module will disallow the use of self-signed (or certificates with expired CA) if "verify" is set to False - the requests won't be sent to the backend at all. 

So I strongly encourage asking deployers to use verifiable CA Signed certificates in production deployments - I suggested that you include that bit in the release note, but I see that you're probably hesitating to do that. I will leave that up to you...

The focus of the performance evaluation and the optimization is AIO configuration. Resource reduction (scale down) and SYSINV optimizations are restricted to specific scenarios of one core (scale down) and local operations (sysinv). The scale down will take place in case of single core allocation respecting existing worker allocation rules. In case of small footprints, the system defines the number of workers based on number of platform cores (in case of AIO) with maximum limit as 2 for AIO-SX and 3 for AIO-DX (linear scalability based on the number of platform cores). The proposed changes would not change the existing rule. With the relaxation of the minimum limit (from 2 to 1), the system would scale down the number of threads to the minimum.

Why does the library assert and exit when it hits an internal error? Shouldn't it just return an error code to the caller and continue running?

The approach taken by the authors and maintainers of the library has always been that a library which encounters an internal error can no longer be trusted. If the internal error cannot be handled, the library should assert and exit. Trying to continue running after an unhandled error may cause unexpected results because the internal program state can not be trusted.

Sometimes an assert indicates a bug in the library. For those situations, we politely request a small code example that reproduces the problem so that we can permanently fix it.
